Dear Amy Elizabeth Harding:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 4/05/2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (b) Within 120 calendar days after the
initial removal and at least once every 90
calendar days thereafter.
Two of the eight foster child records reviewed had at least one USP that was late
for the time period established by this rule.
Repeat Violation Established
Interim dated 7/11/2023, CAP approved 7/14/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (3) When case responsibility changes from 1
child placing agency to another child placing
agency, a modified service plan must be
completed within 30 calendar days of the
change in agency responsibility if no other plan
is done within 30 days. The plan must address

why the agency responsibility changed and
whether there are any modifications to existing
service plans.
One of the eight foster child records reviewed did not include a modified service
plan within 30 days of the change in case responsibilities from another agency to
this agency.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans
• (2) An agency shall complete written service
plans for each child and parent or parents, as
follows:
• (a) Within 30 calendar days from removal
from the home.
One of the eight foster child records reviewed contained an initial service plan
that was completed outside the time frame established by this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12422 Foster care case record
• (3) The record must contain all the following
information:
(e) Change of placement documentation as
required by R 400.12405.
One of the four discharged foster child records reviewed did not have change in
placement/closing documentation completed within the time frame established by
this rule. In this example the discharge date was identified as 1/19/2024 and the
discharge documentation was completed 2/27/2024.
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is used
to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety
concerns and the safety plan, and any
recommendations made for the family during the FTM.
The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, must be
completed for every FTM.

Three of the eight foster child records and one of the three independent living
youth records reviewed did not include the required Family Team Meeting
documentation for compliance with this standard.
Repeat Violation Established
Interim dated 7/11/2023, CAP approved 7/14/2023.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were 3 incidents to assess corporal punishment during this licensing period.
Special Evaluation report #2024C00001169 involved a relative caregiver giving a
grandchild a birthday spanking. This was not harsh or a disciplinary method and
noncompliance was not established.
Special Evaluation report #2023C0000487 involved a foster parent restraining a
youth by grabbing the youths coat when the youth was attempting to truant. This
was determined to be reasonable for the circumstances and noncompliance was
not established.
Special Evaluation report #2024C0001358 involved an incident where a youth
struck a foster parent, and the foster parent allegedly restrained the youth. The
findings determined the foster parent deescalated the situation by providing
distance from the combative youth, so noncompliance was not established.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. The
agency had 7 identified areas of noncompliance as a part of the interim evaluation
completed 7/11/2023. Noncompliance included Rules 418(6), 418(2)(b),
413(1)(f)(i), 327(6)(c), 327(7), 507(1), and FOM 722-06B. The CAP for these
areas of noncompliance was approved 7/14/2023. Areas identified as repeat
noncompliance as a part of this renewal evaluation are Rule 418(2)(b) and FOM
722-06B. The ability of the agency to maintain adequate staffing was a primary
determining factor to establish and maintain compliance. At the time of this review
the agency has been able to stablize their staffing situation.
Special Investigation #2023C0000708SI, intake date 8/17/2023 identified
noncompliance with Rule 400.12206(2). The CAP for this noncompliance was
approved 11/17//2023. Information confirming the termination of the staff member
involved in this situation was received 2/19/2024 and staff training related to the
circumstances of this incident was scheduled for 2/28/2024 were parts of this
CAP.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment was a review of the areas of noncompliance
identified in previous interim evaluations and special investigations. A primary
concern/barrier in establishing compliance is the ability to recruit and maintain
appropriate staffing levels for the number of youth and families being served. The
agency is continuing to modify some processes to overcome this barrier to
establish and maintain compliance. The Chief Administrator Assessment also
included the status of the agency related to Key Performance Indicators.
Financial Overview
The financial audit and current budget received was reviewed and indicated
adequate financial resources are available to meet the needs of those who are
served.
Staff Interviews
The staff interviews were positive and reflected the ongoing transitions occurring
within the agency/program.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency has adequate space, and the building is well maintained. The record
storage is in compliance with licensing rules.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two identified safety alerts.
Safety Alert #1: The home did not have their medications stored securely.

Resolution: This was resolved when the family locked the primary bathroom where
the medication was stored as confirmed by video and photo confirmation.
Safety Alert #2: The home did not have smoke detectors installed in the appropriate
areas of the home.
Resolution: The agency provided the family with the smoke detectors and the proper
installation of the detectors was confirmed with photo confirmation.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
